Key Arguments: The bill infringes on freedom of speech and expression.
It creates two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educators over regular citizens.
Excessive fines and lack of flexibility in the code create a restrictive environment for digital services.
The bill could stifle open and honest discussions and the pursuit of truth.
Industry codes may favor major players and hinder competition, affecting smaller digital services.
The extraterritorial reach of the bill is unworkable and could alienate Australia from the global Internet community.
The bill could impact freedom of political communication and compromise democratic processes.
It is incompatible with international agreements on human rights, particularly regarding freedom of thought and expression.
Notable Quotes: This bill poses a significant risk to silencing their perspectives and opinions disproportionately.
It is an impossible task to ascertain what is true or untrue, as new information regularly emerges.
The bill effectively grants the largest digital services the power to set their own regulations.
The bill's potential impact on religious beliefs and faith-based worldviews raises serious concerns about religious freedom.
